mn127:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn127:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn127:2.1.pli: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:
mn127:2.1.eng: And then the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga addressed a man,
mn127:2.1.comm: For Pañcakaṅga and his role as chamberlain, see note on MN 59:1.3.

mn127:2.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, yenāyasmā anuruddho tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena āyasmato anuruddhassa pāde sirasā vandāhi:
mn127:2.2.eng: “Please, worthy man, go to Venerable Anuruddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him,

mn127:2.3.pli: ‘pañcakaṅgo, bhante, thapati āyasmato anuruddhassa pāde sirasā vandatī’ti;
mn127:2.3.eng: ‘Sir, the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga bows with his head to your feet.’

mn127:2.4.eng: And then ask him whether he

mn127:2.5.pli: ‘adhivāsetu kira, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho pañcakaṅgassa thapatissa svātanāya attacatuttho bhattaṃ;
mn127:2.5.eng: might please accept tomorrow’s meal from Pañcakaṅga together with the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn127:2.6.pli: yena ca kira, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho pagevataraṃ āgaccheyya;
mn127:2.6.eng: And ask whether he might please come earlier than usual,

mn127:2.7.pli: pañcakaṅgo, bhante, thapati bahukicco bahukaraṇīyo rājakaraṇīyenā’”ti.
mn127:2.7.eng: for Pañcakaṅga has many duties, and much work to do for the king.”

mn127:2.8.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so puriso pañcakaṅgassa thapatissa paṭissutvā yenāyasmā anuruddho tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so puriso āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:
mn127:2.8.eng: “Yes, sir,” that man replied. He did as Pañcakaṅga asked, and

mn127:2.9.pli: “pañcakaṅgo, bhante, thapati āyasmato anuruddhassa pāde sirasā vandati, evañca vadeti:

mn127:2.10.pli: ‘adhivāsetu kira, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho pañcakaṅgassa thapatissa svātanāya attacatuttho bhattaṃ;

mn127:2.11.pli: yena ca kira, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho pagevataraṃ āgaccheyya;

mn127:2.12.pli: pañcakaṅgo, bhante, thapati bahukicco bahukaraṇīyo rājakaraṇīyenā’”ti.

mn127:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena pañcakaṅgassa thapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
mn127:3.1.eng: Then when the night had passed, Anuruddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Pañcakaṅga’s home, where he sat on the seat spread out.

mn127:3.2.pli: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
mn127:3.2.eng: Then Pañcakaṅga served and satisfied Anuruddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

mn127:3.3.pli: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn127:3.3.eng: When Anuruddha had eaten and washed his hands and bowl, Pañcakaṅga took a low seat, sat to one side,

mn127:3.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho pañcakaṅgo thapati āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:

mn127:4.1.pli: “Idha maṃ, bhante, therā bhikkhū upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṃsu:
mn127:4.1.eng: “Sir, some senior mendicants have come to me and said,

mn127:4.2.eng: ‘Householder, develop the limitless release of heart.’

mn127:4.4.eng: ‘Householder, develop the expansive release of heart.’

mn127:4.5.pli: Yā cāyaṃ, bhante, appamāṇā cetovimutti yā ca mahaggatā cetovimutti—
mn127:4.5.eng: Now, the limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart:

mn127:4.6.pli: ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca, udāhu ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti?
mn127:4.6.eng: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”
mn127:4.6.comm: At MN 43:29.5, Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta a similar question about different meditative liberations.

mn127:5.1.pli: “Tena hi, gahapati, taṃyevettha paṭibhātu, apaṇṇakante ito bhavissatī”ti.
mn127:5.1.eng: “Well then, householder, let me know what you think about this. Afterwards you’ll get it without fail.”
mn127:5.1.comm: “Without fail” renders apaṇṇaka, for which see note on MN 60:4.3. It’s an unusual response. As apaṇṇaka means a “set without a fifth”, Anuruddha might be punning on Pañcakaṅga’s name, which means, “a set of five items”.

mn127:5.3.pli: ‘yā cāyaṃ appamāṇā cetovimutti yā ca mahaggatā cetovimutti ime dhammā ekatthā byañjanameva nānan’”ti.
mn127:5.3.eng: The limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”

mn127:6.1.pli: “Yā cāyaṃ, gahapati, appamāṇā cetovimutti yā ca mahaggatā cetovimutti ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca.
mn127:6.1.eng: “The limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart differ in both meaning and phrasing.

mn127:6.2.pli: Tadamināpetaṃ, gahapati, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca.
mn127:6.2.eng: This is a way to understand how these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.

mn127:7.1.eng: And what is the limitless release of the heart?
mn127:7.1.comm: “Limitless” is appamāṇa. This set of four meditations is known in later traditions as either the “divine meditations” (brahmavihārā) or the “immeasurables” (appamaññā).

mn127:7.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ tathā tatiyaṃ tathā catutthaṃ; iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharati.
mn127:7.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

mn127:7.3.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …

mn127:7.4.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …

mn127:7.5.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ tathā tatiyaṃ tathā catutthaṃ; iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharati.
mn127:7.5.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

mn127:7.6.eng: This is called the limitless release of the heart.

mn127:8.1.eng: And what is the expansive release of the heart?
mn127:8.1.comm: “Expansive” renders mahaggata, literally “grown great”. This features as a state of mind that is developed in satipaṭṭhāna (MN 10:34.10), and which is known with psychic powers (MN 6:16.10). It also appears just above next to “limitless” in the description of the divine meditations, a detail that perhaps prompted Pañcakaṅga’s question.

mn127:8.2.pli: Idha, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
mn127:8.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates focused on pervading the extent of a single tree root as expansive.
mn127:8.2.comm: This meditation practice is unique to this passage. It might be compared with the practice of emptiness at MN 121:4.1, which likewise moves from a perception of one’s limited surroundings towards something more universal. The meaning of “pervading” (pharitvā) might be understood in the same sense as it is found in the divine meditations, where I have translated it as “spread”. The sutta below, however, treats it as the spreading of light. In this interpretation, the “expansive” practice is a method of spreading love (etc.) by gradually expanding the perception of the field of love. The final extent is the land bordered by ocean, beyond which the mind become “limitless like the great ocean” (MN 72:20.2). In other words, the “expansive” liberation leads to the “limitless” liberation.

mn127:8.3.eng: This is called the expansive release of the heart.

mn127:8.4.pli: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā rukkhamūlāni mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
mn127:8.4.eng: Also, a mendicant meditates focused on pervading the extent of two or three tree roots …

mn127:8.6.pli: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṃ gāmakkhettaṃ mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.

mn127:8.8.pli: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā gāmakkhettāni mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.

mn127:8.10.pli: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṃ mahārajjaṃ mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.

mn127:8.12.pli: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā mahārajjāni mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.

mn127:8.14.pli: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā samuddapariyantaṃ pathaviṃ mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.

mn127:8.15.eng: This too is called the expansive release of the heart.

mn127:8.16.pli: Iminā kho etaṃ, gahapati, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca.
mn127:8.16.eng: This is a way to understand how these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.

mn127:9.1.eng: Householder, there are these four kinds of rebirth in a future life.
mn127:9.1.comm: “Rebirth in a future life” renders bhavūpapatti. This section explains how the meditation one develops can shape one’s rebirth.

mn127:9.3.pli: Idha, gahapati, ekacco ‘parittābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
mn127:9.3.eng: Take someone who meditates focused on pervading ‘limited radiance’.

mn127:9.4.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parittābhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
mn127:9.4.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of limited radiance.
mn127:9.4.comm: The gods of limited radiance are mentioned at MN 41:18–42.22, where they are reborn due to a limited practice of the second absorption.

mn127:9.5.pli: Idha pana, gahapati, ekacco ‘appamāṇābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
mn127:9.5.eng: Next, take someone who meditates focused on pervading ‘limitless radiance’.

mn127:9.6.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā appamāṇābhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
mn127:9.6.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of limitless radiance.

mn127:9.7.pli: Idha pana, gahapati, ekacco ‘saṅkiliṭṭhābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
mn127:9.7.eng: Next, take someone who meditates focused on pervading ‘corrupted radiance’.
mn127:9.7.comm: Normally the suttas maintain a clear distinction between the “corrupted” (saṅkiliṭṭha) mind that is purified before attaining the radiance of absorption. This passage, however, suggests that things might not always be so clear-cut.

mn127:9.8.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā saṅkiliṭṭhābhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
mn127:9.8.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of corrupted radiance.

mn127:9.9.pli: Idha pana, gahapati, ekacco ‘parisuddhābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
mn127:9.9.eng: Next, take someone who meditates focused on pervading ‘pure radiance’.

mn127:9.10.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parisuddhābhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
mn127:9.10.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of pure radiance.

mn127:9.11.eng: These are the four kinds of rebirth in a future life.

mn127:10.1.pli: Hoti kho so, gahapati, samayo, yā tā devatā ekajjhaṃ sannipatanti, tāsaṃ ekajjhaṃ sannipatitānaṃ vaṇṇanānattañhi kho paññāyati no ca ābhānānattaṃ.
mn127:10.1.eng: There comes a time, householder, when the deities gather together as one. When they do so, a difference in their color is evident, but not in their radiance.

mn127:10.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, gahapati, puriso sambahulāni telappadīpāni ekaṃ gharaṃ paveseyya.
mn127:10.2.eng: It’s like when a person brings several oil lamps into one house.

mn127:10.3.pli: Tesaṃ ekaṃ gharaṃ pavesitānaṃ accinānattañhi kho paññāyetha, no ca ābhānānattaṃ;
mn127:10.3.eng: You can detect a difference in their flames, but not in their radiance.

mn127:10.4.pli: evameva kho, gahapati, hoti kho so samayo, yā tā devatā ekajjhaṃ sannipatanti tāsaṃ ekajjhaṃ sannipatitānaṃ vaṇṇanānattañhi kho paññāyati, no ca ābhānānattaṃ.
mn127:10.4.eng: In the same way, when the deities gather together as one, a difference in their color is evident, but not in their radiance.

mn127:11.1.pli: Hoti kho so, gahapati, samayo, yā tā devatā tato vipakkamanti, tāsaṃ tato vipakkamantīnaṃ vaṇṇanānattañceva paññāyati ābhānānattañca.
mn127:11.1.eng: There comes a time when those deities go their separate ways. When they do so, a difference both in their color and also in their radiance is evident.

mn127:11.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, gahapati, puriso tāni sambahulāni telappadīpāni tamhā gharā nīhareyya.
mn127:11.2.eng: It’s like when a person takes those several oil lamps out of that house.

mn127:11.3.pli: Tesaṃ tato nīhatānaṃ accinānattañceva paññāyetha ābhānānattañca;
mn127:11.3.eng: You can detect a difference both in their flames and also in their radiance.

mn127:11.4.pli: evameva kho, gahapati, hoti kho so samayo, yā tā devatā tato vipakkamanti, tāsaṃ tato vipakkamantīnaṃ vaṇṇanānattañceva paññāyati ābhānānattañca.
mn127:11.4.eng: In the same way, when the deities go their separate ways, a difference both in their color and also in their radiance is evident.

mn127:12.1.pli: Na kho, gahapati, tāsaṃ devatānaṃ evaṃ hoti:
mn127:12.1.eng: It’s not that those deities think,

mn127:12.2.pli: ‘idaṃ amhākaṃ niccanti vā dhuvanti vā sassatanti vā’, api ca yattha yattheva tā devatā abhinivisanti tattha tattheva tā devatā abhiramanti.
mn127:12.2.eng: ‘What we have is permanent, lasting, and eternal.’ Rather, wherever those deities cling, that’s where they take pleasure.

mn127:12.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, gahapati, makkhikānaṃ kājena vā piṭakena vā harīyamānānaṃ na evaṃ hoti:
mn127:12.3.eng: It’s like when flies are being carried along on a carrying-pole or basket. It’s not that they think,

mn127:12.4.pli: ‘idaṃ amhākaṃ niccanti vā dhuvanti vā sassatanti vā’, api ca yattha yattheva tā makkhikā abhinivisanti tattha tattheva tā makkhikā abhiramanti;
mn127:12.4.eng: ‘What we have is permanent, lasting, and eternal.’ Rather, wherever those flies cling, that’s where they take pleasure.

mn127:12.5.pli: evameva kho, gahapati, tāsaṃ devatānaṃ na evaṃ hoti:
mn127:12.5.eng: In the same way, it’s not that those deities think,

mn127:12.6.pli: ‘idaṃ amhākaṃ niccanti vā dhuvanti vā sassatanti vā’, api ca yattha yattheva tā devatā abhinivisanti tattha tattheva tā devatā abhiramantī”ti.
mn127:12.6.eng: ‘What we have is permanent, lasting, and eternal.’ Rather, wherever those deities cling, that’s where they take pleasure.”
mn127:12.6.comm: This example shows that “craving for rebirth” need not be conscious.

mn127:13.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sabhiyo kaccāno āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:
mn127:13.1.eng: When he had spoken, Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna said to Venerable Anuruddha:
mn127:13.1.comm: We meet Sabhiya Kaccāna also at SN 44.1, where he is questioned by Vacchagotta. His verses are at Thag 4.3. The conversion of a wanderer named Sabhiya is recorded in Snp 3.6; this might be the same person.

mn127:13.3.pli: Atthi ca me ettha uttariṃ paṭipucchitabbaṃ.
mn127:13.3.eng: I have a further question about this.

mn127:13.4.pli: Yā tā, bhante, devatā ābhā sabbā tā parittābhā udāhu santettha ekaccā devatā appamāṇābhā”ti?
mn127:13.4.eng: Do all the radiant deities have limited radiance, or do some there have limitless radiance?”

mn127:13.5.pli: “Tadaṅgena kho, āvuso kaccāna, santettha ekaccā devatā parittābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā appamāṇābhā”ti.
mn127:13.5.eng: “In that respect, Reverend Kaccāna, some deities there have limited radiance, while some have limitless radiance.”
mn127:13.5.comm: For tadaṅgena in the sense “in that respect”, see AN 9.33:1.3.

mn127:14.1.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhante anuruddha, hetu ko paccayo yena tāsaṃ devatānaṃ ekaṃ devanikāyaṃ upapannānaṃ santettha ekaccā devatā parittābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā appamāṇābhā”ti?
mn127:14.1.eng: “What is the cause, Honorable Anuruddha, what is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have limited radiance, while some have limitless radiance?”

mn127:14.2.pli: “Tena hāvuso kaccāna, taṃyevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
mn127:14.2.eng: “Well then, Reverend Kaccāna, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

mn127:14.3.eng: What do you think, Reverend Kaccāna?

mn127:14.4.pli: yvāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā rukkhamūlāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
mn127:14.4.eng: Which of these two kinds of mental development is more expansive: when a mendicant meditates focused on pervading as expansive the extent of a single tree root, or two or three tree roots?”

mn127:14.5.pli: imāsaṃ ubhinnaṃ cittabhāvanānaṃ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?

mn127:14.6.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā rukkhamūlāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
mn127:14.6.eng: “When a mendicant meditates on two or three tree roots.”

mn127:14.9.pli: yvāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā rukkhamūlāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṃ gāmakkhettaṃ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
mn127:14.9.eng: Which of these two kinds of mental development is more expansive: when a mendicant meditates focused on pervading as expansive the extent of two or three tree roots, or a single village district …

mn127:14.10.pli: imāsaṃ ubhinnaṃ cittabhāvanānaṃ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?

mn127:14.11.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṃ gāmakkhettaṃ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—

mn127:14.13.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, āvuso kaccāna, yvāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṃ gāmakkhettaṃ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā gāmakkhettāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—

mn127:14.14.pli: imāsaṃ ubhinnaṃ cittabhāvanānaṃ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?

mn127:14.15.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā gāmakkhettāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—

mn127:14.17.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, āvuso kaccāna, yvāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā gāmakkhettāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṃ mahārajjaṃ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—

mn127:14.18.pli: imāsaṃ ubhinnaṃ cittabhāvanānaṃ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?

mn127:14.19.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṃ mahārajjaṃ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—

mn127:14.21.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, āvuso kaccāna, yvāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṃ mahārajjaṃ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā mahārajjāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—

mn127:14.22.pli: imāsaṃ ubhinnaṃ cittabhāvanānaṃ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?

mn127:14.23.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā mahārajjāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—

mn127:14.25.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, āvuso kaccāna, yvāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā mahārajjāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṃ bhikkhu yāvatā samuddapariyantaṃ pathaviṃ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—

mn127:14.26.pli: imāsaṃ ubhinnaṃ cittabhāvanānaṃ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?

mn127:14.27.pli: “Yvāyaṃ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā samuddapariyantaṃ pathaviṃ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
mn127:14.27.eng: “When a mendicant meditates on this land surrounded by ocean.”

mn127:14.29.pli: “Ayaṃ kho, āvuso kaccāna, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena tāsaṃ devatānaṃ ekaṃ devanikāyaṃ upapannānaṃ santettha ekaccā devatā parittābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā appamāṇābhā”ti.
mn127:14.29.eng: “This is the cause, Reverend Kaccāna, this is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have limited radiance, while some have limitless radiance.”

mn127:15.2.pli: Atthi ca me ettha uttariṃ paṭipucchitabbaṃ.
mn127:15.2.eng: I have a further question about this.

mn127:15.3.pli: Yāvatā, bhante, devatā ābhā sabbā tā saṅkiliṭṭhābhā udāhu santettha ekaccā devatā parisuddhābhā”ti?
mn127:15.3.eng: Do all the radiant deities have corrupted radiance, or do some there have pure radiance?”

mn127:15.4.pli: “Tadaṅgena kho, āvuso kaccāna, santettha ekaccā devatā saṅkiliṭṭhābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā parisuddhābhā”ti.
mn127:15.4.eng: “In that respect, Reverend Kaccāna, some deities there have corrupted radiance, while some have pure radiance.”

mn127:16.1.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhante, anuruddha, hetu ko paccayo, yena tāsaṃ devatānaṃ ekaṃ devanikāyaṃ upapannānaṃ santettha ekaccā devatā saṅkiliṭṭhābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā parisuddhābhā”ti?
mn127:16.1.eng: “What is the cause, Venerable Anuruddha, what is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have corrupted radiance, while some have pure radiance?”

mn127:16.2.eng: “Well then, Reverend Kaccāna, I shall give you a simile.

mn127:16.3.pli: Upamāyapidhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
mn127:16.3.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

mn127:16.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso kaccāna, telappadīpassa jhāyato telampi aparisuddhaṃ vaṭṭipi aparisuddhā.
mn127:16.4.eng: Suppose an oil lamp was burning with impure oil and impure wick.

mn127:16.5.pli: So telassapi aparisuddhattā vaṭṭiyāpi aparisuddhattā andhandhaṃ viya jhāyati;
mn127:16.5.eng: Because of the impurity of the oil and the wick it burns dimly, as it were.

mn127:16.6.pli: evameva kho, āvuso kaccāna, idhekacco bhikkhu ‘saṅkiliṭṭhābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati,
mn127:16.6.eng: In the same way, take some mendicant who meditates focused on pervading ‘corrupted radiance’.

mn127:16.7.pli: tassa kāyaduṭṭhullampi na suppaṭippassaddhaṃ hoti, thinamiddhampi na susamūhataṃ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccampi na suppaṭivinītaṃ hoti.
mn127:16.7.eng: Their physical discomfort is not completely settled, their dullness and drowsiness is not completely eradicated, and their restlessness and remorse are not completely eliminated.

mn127:16.8.pli: So kāyaduṭṭhullassapi na suppaṭippassaddhattā thinamiddhassapi na susamūhatattā uddhaccakukkuccassapi na suppaṭivinītattā andhandhaṃ viya jhāyati.
mn127:16.8.eng: Because of this they practice absorption dimly, as it were.

mn127:16.9.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā saṅkiliṭṭhābhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
mn127:16.9.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of corrupted radiance.

mn127:16.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso kaccāna, telappadīpassa jhāyato telampi parisuddhaṃ vaṭṭipi parisuddhā.
mn127:16.10.eng: Suppose an oil lamp was burning with pure oil and pure wick.

mn127:16.11.pli: So telassapi parisuddhattā vaṭṭiyāpi parisuddhattā na andhandhaṃ viya jhāyati;
mn127:16.11.eng: Because of the purity of the oil and the wick it doesn’t burn dimly, as it were.

mn127:16.12.pli: evameva kho, āvuso kaccāna, idhekacco bhikkhu ‘parisuddhābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
mn127:16.12.eng: In the same way, take some mendicant who meditates focused on pervading ‘pure radiance’.

mn127:16.13.pli: Tassa kāyaduṭṭhullampi suppaṭippassaddhaṃ hoti, thinamiddhampi susamūhataṃ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccampi suppaṭivinītaṃ hoti.
mn127:16.13.eng: Their physical discomfort is completely settled, their dullness and drowsiness is completely eradicated, and their restlessness and remorse is completely eliminated.

mn127:16.14.pli: So kāyaduṭṭhullassapi suppaṭippassaddhattā thinamiddhassapi susamūhatattā uddhaccakukkuccassapi suppaṭivinītattā na andhandhaṃ viya jhāyati.
mn127:16.14.eng: Because of this they don’t practice absorption dimly, as it were.

mn127:16.15.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā parisuddhābhānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
mn127:16.15.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of pure radiance.

mn127:16.16.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso kaccāna, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena tāsaṃ devatānaṃ ekaṃ devanikāyaṃ upapannānaṃ santettha ekaccā devatā saṅkiliṭṭhābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā parisuddhābhā”ti.
mn127:16.16.eng: “This is the cause, Reverend Kaccāna, this is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have corrupted radiance, while some have pure radiance.”

mn127:17.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sabhiyo kaccāno āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:
mn127:17.1.eng: When he had spoken, Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna said to Venerable Anuruddha,

mn127:17.4.pli: ‘evaṃ me sutan’ti vā ‘evaṃ arahati bhavitun’ti vā;
mn127:17.4.eng: ‘So I have heard’ or ‘It ought to be like this.’
mn127:17.4.comm: The phrase cited by Sabhiya here, “so I have heard” (evaṁ me sutaṁ), is the standard opening for Buddhist suttas. This passage illustrates that this tag was used in order to indicate that the speaker was not present at the events, but “heard” about them. This is in contrast with the phrase “I heard and learned this in the presence” (sammukhā sutaṁ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ), which is used when reporting a teaching heard directly from the Buddha, eg. SN 55.52:5.1, SN 22.90:9.1, MN 47:10.7, etc.

mn127:17.5.pli: atha ca pana, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho ‘evampi tā devatā, itipi tā devatā’tveva bhāsati.
mn127:17.5.eng: Rather, you say: ‘These deities are like this, those deities are like that.’

mn127:17.7.pli: ‘addhā āyasmatā anuruddhena tāhi devatāhi saddhiṃ sannivutthapubbañceva sallapitapubbañca sākacchā ca samāpajjitapubbā’”ti.
mn127:17.7.eng: ‘Clearly, Venerable Anuruddha has previously lived together with those deities, conversed, and engaged in discussion.’”

mn127:17.8.pli: “Addhā kho ayaṃ, āvuso kaccāna, āsajja upanīya vācā bhāsitā,
mn127:17.8.eng: “Your words are clearly invasive and intrusive, Reverend Kaccāna.
mn127:17.8.comm: Sabhiya is bluntly asking about Anuruddha’s personal meditation attainments. It is a minor offence to declare these to lay people, but they may be discussed among monastics (Bu Pc 8). In this case, Anuruddha is speaking to a monastic while at least one lay person can overhear, a situation not addressed in the Vinaya.

mn127:17.10.pli: ‘dīgharattaṃ kho me, āvuso kaccāna, tāhi devatāhi saddhiṃ sannivutthapubbañceva sallapitapubbañca sākacchā ca samāpajjitapubbā’”ti.
mn127:17.10.eng: For a long time I have previously lived together with those deities, conversed, and engaged in discussion.”

mn127:18.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sabhiyo kaccāno pañcakaṅgaṃ thapatiṃ etadavoca:
mn127:18.1.eng: When he had spoken, Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna said to Pañcakaṅga the chamberlain,

mn127:18.3.pli: yaṃ tvañceva taṃ kaṅkhādhammaṃ pahāsi, mayañcimaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ alatthamhā savanāyā”ti.
mn127:18.3.eng: to have given up your state of uncertainty, and to have got the chance to listen to this exposition of the teaching.”
